scientists should try chinese tea called puerh, it sobers people up almost completely in 30-40 minutes. there are two varieties of this tea - shen, which is kind of similar to green tea, and there is shu, which is fermented and kind of black. both work well, but while trying this out systematically on people around, i noticed that shen puerh works better. once i needed to sober up a friend who had been drinking for two days - approx. 10-12 litres of beer and unknown amount distilled drinks. it took only three cups of shen puerh brewed according to standarts to sober him up completely and after an hour we sat and talked until the very morning like nothing happened.
p.s. it works miracles with hangover too, but be sure to eat at least something before, otherwise it can upset stomach in such delicately brutal state of being.

I believe Scishow made a video a few years back contradicting this claim of 'no means to sober up faster'. Or at least in part. They reported on a study that had found that drinking sprite (among other tested drinks) helped break down the compound that causes headaches while drinking black tea extends the time it takes to do the same. So while it may not help with feeling drunk, it does speed up recovery time - which at least for me is part of sobering up.

Relatively large doses of fructose are somewhat effective in sobering up faster.

"Here we show that fructose, at a dose of 1 g / kg, fulfils the criteria for such an agent. When ingested by healthy volunteers who had imbibed ethanol equivalent to 8 standard tots, it reduced the time required to attain a legal blood alcohol level (50 mg%) by approximately 70 min (n = 9)."

"Effect of oral fructose on ethanol elimination from the bloodstream : research in action"

A hangover is a sign that you are dehydrated and that is what a hangover actually is.

So, do this:

1. Before you go out fill the kettle with water and set it to boil.

2. Let the kettle cool down naturally - since you are out getting drunk this will not be noticeable.

3. When you come home, fill 3 pint glasses with the water from the kettle and drink them.

4. Goto bed and sleep.

When you waken, you will not have a hangover.

0:48 - This is false. There is L-Theanine a natural anti-oxidant found in green/white tea is used to break down alcohol to acetaldehyde, which can make you feel drunker faster.
Also, the circumin in tumeric, a spice used abunduntly in Indian food, helps in breaking down acetaldehyde.
These two will reduce the damage done by alcohol and make you sober up faster.

This is obviously what the average person can do to minimize damage done by alcohol consumption.
In other words, drink some green tea and eat some Indian food before going out drinking.

I don't think this works for two reasons.

1.) In order for this to work, you'd have to be breathing out about 21 times the amount of ethanol you were before hand. Twice as much? Maybe. Three times as much? Possibly. But 21 times as much? That's unbelievable.

2.) Even if you do breath out 21 times as much ethanol under these circumstances, you blood CO2 levels would go up. As this happened your lungs would again start exchanging CO2 with the air you're breathing in. At this point the CO2 would get in the way of the ethanol and you should be back to square one. This is pure chemistry here. There's just no way to keep your lungs from getting rid of the CO2 that builds up in your blood. At least not without sending someone to the ER for hypercapnia.

Some peeps mentioned that holding your breath or smoking makes you get drunk faster, so I spent like an hour nerding about whether that's true. Figured I'd repost my thoughts in a fresh thread.

​The TL;DR is that both smoking or holding your breath would not make you get drunk faster because your body compensates, but it might be possible with some forms of chronic obstructive pulmonary disease (COPD). The details are below:

In short-term smokers with healthy lung tissue--and we're talking about individuals who have been smoking consistently for less than several months--we'd be stating that, hypothetically, cigarette smoking is similar to holding your breath. Although this is true if you neglect the effects of nicotine and CO, you'll notice that holding your breath for some duration results in a marked increase in depth and rate of respiration once you start breathing again. This is also the case with cigarettes: people need to breath more between drags of their cigarettes than they would have to if they weren't smoking. However, periods of increased respiration between drags are balanced with periods of decreased respiration during drags and there is basically no net hyperventilation over time. Blood-ethanol levels would likely be similar over time in short-term smoking individuals versus non-smoking individuals.

As an aside, the increased need to respire between drags might not be so noticeable due to nicotine's stimulating effects on vasoconstriction and heart rate, which could increase the efficiency of gas exchange. In this context, however, ventilatory effort is much more important for gas exchange than perfusion of blood in the lungs, and this is for reasons that are beyond the scope of the point I'm making. I would guess that the activating effects of nicotine on the central nervous system give some people the impression that they are more sober than they really are. I don't know if this latter point is true, but that would be an avenue to investigate and I would assume that literature on it exists.

Smoking for months or even as little as a year can lead to irreversible changes to the tissues of your lungs, which causes a decreased ability to exchange gasses (for more reading: https://www.ncbi.nlm.nih.gov/pmc/articles/PMC4516194/ ). Hypothetically, in some habitually-smoking people, alcohol could be retained for longer due to the damage that their lungs have sustained. Alas, the body would still be sensitive to the decreased ability to absorb O2 or exhale CO2, and, as a result, induce an increase in the respiratory rate. In this case, I would think that the ethanol retained due to the inability to exchange gas would be lost due to the increased respiratory rate.

Many individuals that smoke develop what's called COPD, which, although preventable (by quitting) and treatable (with lots of meds), is irreversible, worsens over time, and variable in its presentation and resultant effects on ventilatory drive. Classically, individuals diagnosed with COPD fall into two categories: those who breath relatively faster and more shallow due to decreased ability to exchange gas (similar to what was mentioned in the previous paragraph), which is associated more with emphysema, and those who breath relatively more *slowly due to outflow obstruction that causes the lungs to be overinflated, which is associated with chronic bronchitis. Often times, the presentation can be mixed, so it's just a stereotypical way to characterize things, but the point here is that respiratory rate can be *decreased in some individuals with COPD. For these individuals, it might be possible that they'd retain more ethanol in their blood for longer. It's basically like they're somewhat holding their breath for the rest of their lives--pretty horrific to witness and surprisingly common.


Thanks for giving me an excuse to think about pulmonology and procrastinating what I'm actually supposed to be studying! Check out any pulmonary physiology/pathology review if you want a source for most of what I wrote.

PSA: although COPD and atherosclerosis are irreversible and cancer is often deadly, risk and severity tend to get worse with the amount of time one smokes. Quality and duration of life improve dramatically with quitting. Here're some unsolicited resources to quit smoking if you or someone you care about are thinking about it: https://smokefree.gov/

* Edit: I wouldn't expect a reduced respiratory rate compared to a healthy person, just compared to most people with COPD and relative to their body's oxygen demands.
WTH

The best way to get sober, in my experience (sample size of one), is to eat something along side drinking alcohol in MODERATION and drinking a chaser like water or a sports drink. If it's light beer, it could be french fries or potato wedges that do the trick. A darker and richer beer will require something equally hearty like a thick burger patty on a potato bun with a side of fries. Wine requires a full meal with 2 sides and an entree. The big factors for me are how much I have drank to how much I've ate which requires me to strictly moderate both and give myself some time for things to metabolize. Doing that, I will usually feel and act fine within an hour after the last sip. I would not suggest someone drive in that time or 45 minutes after that time elapses.

Hangover strategy: Halfway between drinking and hangover (i.e. pee time), flex your muscles.
Start with the leg muscles, since they are the largest. Do ballet-style leg lifts: front, back and out to the side. 10 reps x 3.
Flex all the other muscles you can manage. Be spastic for a couple of minutes.
Go to bed. You will awake with a much-diminished hangover.

It's actually untrue that we have found no way to speed up the metabolism of ethanol by the liver.

Sugar, specifically Fructose- fruit sugar has been shown multiple times to modestly speed up ethanol metabolism, admittedly relatively modestly, and you need to eat an ungodly amount like 100g to see the effect.

Amounts large enough that there would be a real concern of exacerbating any liver problems of the alcohol consumption so probably not a wise idea to actually use.
And that is why o2 is used as a treatment for vasodilation headaches (Cluster Headache, TGN, Migraine)

My husband is a forensic toxicologist. His lab would host a party that would experiment with BAC. You would drink a measured amount and have a blood draw and take a breathalyzer. Then everyone would experiment with ways to sober up more quickly. Basically any form of cardio helps your body metabolize alcohol faster. It’s not enough to stave off alcohol poisoning but if you feel you had one drink too many a bit of vigorous dancing will help you feel a little more normal.

*This method is not reliable enough to bring you to a level where you are safe to drive if you drank too much. If you have any question whether you’re sober enough to drive the answer is no and you need to find another way home.*
